There are many who believe that the Moon is, at least to some extent, hollow. Seismic tests carried out on the Moon's surface, by equipment installed in one of the Moon rovers, revealed a ringing sound "like a bell" coming from inside the Moon. The conclusion was that there are at least some major cavities inside the Moon - the Moon is not solid. Perhaps then, if we are non-believers in alien beings, flying saucers and all that stuff, we take the purely scientific view - that is to say, these hollow segments of the Moon MIGHT contain gas, derived from some geological activity aeons ago but trapped inside these cavities for all that time until now. Small amounts of methane, carbon dioxide, ammonia, and water were also detected. In addition, argon-40 was detected, and its abundance increased at times of high seismic activity.") as these gases interact with the solar wind, they could react similarly to how the Auroras on the Polar regions of our planet occur. ( "How auroras form. Auroras occur when charged particles (electrons and protons) collide with gases in Earth's upper atmosphere. Those collisions produce tiny flashes that fill the sky with colorful lights. As billions of flashes occur in sequence, the auroras appear to move or " dance " in the sky.') Although the Earth has a magnetic field, which is responsible for the Auroras. However, Boston University Center for Space Physics' study 30 Sept 1991 states: ". . .our moon does indeed have an atmosphere consisting of some unusual gases, including sodium and potassium, which are not found in the atmospheres of Earth, Mars or Venus. It's an infinitesimal amount of air when compared to Earth's atmosphere. At sea level on Earth, we breathe in an atmosphere where each cubic centimeter contains 10,000,000,000,000,000,000 molecules; by comparison the lunar atmosphere has less than 1,000,000 molecules in the same volume.
Pretty thin soup. Sodium and potassium get kicked up by photons hitting the surface. There's also argon, helium and other minor components. So, whether by ionic or fluorescent emission, the moon's atmosphere does glow. Unless one wants to argue about the glow not being restricted to the poles by a magnetic field, or airglow, that glow counts as an aurora."
